abstract.p: Background. The Rasch model prescribes procedures to ensure that a scale constructed from multiple items conforms to fundamental requirements of interval scales of measurement. Objective. To test the Rasch properties of the domains of the World Health Organization Quality of Life Instrument–abbreviated version (WHOQOL-BREF) in depressed patients from primary care settings. Design. Cross-sectional, cross-national study. Setting. Primary care. Patients. The sample consisted of 1193 patients having a confirmed diagnosis of depression from 6 countries (Australia, Brazil, Israel, Russia, Spain, and the United States) involved in the Longitudinal Investigation of Depression Outcomes (LIDO) study. Measurements. The Composite International Diagnostic Interview (CIDI) diagnosed depression, whereas the Center for Epidemiological Studies Depression Scale (CES-D) assessed severity of depression. The WHOQOL-BREF measured generic quality of life (QOL). Results. Three of the 4 WHOQOL-BREF domains (physical, psychological, and environment) conform to the Rasch model expectations, following adjustments required mainly because of individual item misfit or differential item functioning (DIF) due to age or country. The social domain showed relatively poor psychometric properties, as observed in previous studies. Conclusions. The Rasch analysis demonstrated that, with some modifications, all domains of the WHOQOL-BREF, except for the social domain, provide an interval scale measure of generic subjective QOL in the context of depressed primary care patients in 6 countries worldwide.

body.p: The WHOQOL-BREF, the abbreviated generic measure of quality of life (QOL) developed by the World Health Organization, was developed simultaneously in several cultures and languages under the framework of classical test theory (CTT). It has 26 items covering 4 domains: physical, psychological, social, and environment.1,2

Under the framework of CTT, it is common to use raw scores—the counts of observed responses. This use of raw scores in calculating the sample mean and variance is potentially misleading as raw scores relate ordinally but not necessarily linearly to the underlying construct. Despite the widespread use of raw scores, they do not have scale qualities that support valid mathematical operations, such as the calculation of means or standard deviations, and the analysis of such data may often mask ineffective treatment or hide effective methods.3

The Rasch model4 is a theory about the distribution of item response patterns one would expect to observe under fundamental requirements of measurement5—that is, one is only justified in constructing a scale from a set of items, if the probabilities of people’s responses to the items conform to some principles. Also, this technique may be used as a complementary tool for validation studies that used CTT6–8 as it is an important step to ensure the mathematical/statistical validity of the operations performed by research instruments. This model presents a set of analyses to obtain a variable with additive structure, which, in turn, is suitable to be measured on an interval scale.4 Rasch analysis computer programs (such as the RUMM 2020,9 which was used in this analysis) perform a logistic transformation of the item and person data to convert the ordinal scale data into interval scale data. The Rasch methodology used in this article is detailed elsewhere10 and has been increasingly used.11–23

The construction of QOL instruments that satisfy the requirements of the Rasch model may be of special interest to decision analysts who use QOL as a measure of the outcome of health treatments and wish to apply meaningful multiplication to it (multiply QOL by time in the health status; multiply that by the probability of being in that health status). To illustrate this relevance, 5 health-related QOL indexes (EQ-5D, HUI2, HUI3, QWB-SA, and SF-6D) have recently been compared using an item response theory (IRT) model.24

The Rasch model and IRT 1-parameter models can be construed as very similar as both are typically used to construct tests of ability, using items of varying difficulty. However, Andrich25 argues they work within different paradigms: The IRT modeler seeks the model that best accounts for the data, whereas the Rasch modeler accepts the form of the model and evaluates whether the data fit that form. If the data fit the Rasch model, then each person’s ability level and each item’s difficulty may be placed on an interval scale, thereby making these estimates suitable for the calculation of means and variances. In addition, this model provides a direct estimate of the modeled error variance for each estimate of a person’s ability and an item’s difficulty. These standard errors provide a quantification of the precision of every person’s measure and every item’s difficulty and can be used to describe a range within which each item’s “true” difficulty or person’s “true” ability falls.26–28 In addition, by using the Rasch model, it is possible to determine whether the items that constitute a particular measure (in our case, one of the WHOQOL-BREF domains) behave differently for people in different groups (e.g., culture, age, or gender). The ability to identify items that vary in this way is especially valuable in the assessment of cross-cultural invariance of research instruments.29 Although many statistical procedures may be used to examine the cultural item equivalence of tests, the Rasch model is one of the most well-known and useful statistical tools for identifying item bias due to cultural differences.30

This article reports on an investigation of the cross-cultural stability of the scale qualities of the 4 domains of the WHOQOL-BREF when applied to depressed individuals. If the QOL measure should demonstrate good quality when used with depressed people, stably across cultures including non-European cultures,31,32 then it could be used on a global basis to study the important issue of whether depressive symptomatology is related to the QOL score.33–39

The Longitudinal Investigation of Depression Outcomes (LIDO) study was a multicenter, cross-national observational study that followed patients with depressive disorders in primary care settings for 12 months in 6 countries. All LIDO publications that aimed at assessing QOL (measured by the WHOQOL-BREF and the Quality of Life in Depression Scale [QLDS]) concluded that depressed participants have poor QOL, even when other variables are taken into account, such as demographic variables, health status, and severity of depression.40–45

Rasch analysis has been incorporated into the development of the latest measures produced by the WHOQOL Group,46 but the WHOQOL-BREF has not undergone this kind of evaluation yet. Potentially, the LIDO database allows us to empirically test the Rasch measurement properties of the WHOQOL-BREF domains and the invariance of item measures in cross-cultural settings.

sec.title: Method
sec.p: The design, instruments, and methodology of the LIDO study, including sample size estimation, are thoroughly described elsewhere.42,47 In summary, patients attending primary care centers in 6 sites (Barcelona, Spain; Be’er Sheva, Israel; Melbourne, Australia; Porto Alegre, Brazil; Seattle, Washington; and St. Petersburg, Russia) were screened for symptoms of depression. Those meeting inclusion criteria—a new and/or untreated episode and a score of more than 16 on the Center for Epidemiological Studies Depression Scale (CES-D)48—were interviewed and assessed using a standardized diagnostic instrument for major depression, the Composite International Diagnostic Interview (CIDI).49 This article analyzes the baseline data of the sample of the LIDO study.

sec.title: Sample Selection
sec.p: For inclusion in the LIDO study, participants had to be 18 to 75 years old, be a patient in a participating primary care setting, and meet the CIDI criteria for current major depression. They also had to be able and willing to participate in planned visits and/or study-required contacts; provide adequate contact details to ensure follow-up; give written informed consent; read, understand, and complete the self-administered surveys in the primary language at the site; and plan to be available for the 12 months of the study. Individuals were not included if during the recruitment period they a) were receiving treatment for depression or had been treated for depression in the past 3 months, b) had been diagnosed with a major psychiatric disorder or psychosis, or c) had a diagnosis of dementia, Alzheimer disease, or organic brain syndrome.

sec.title: Demographic characteristics
sec.p: Continuous variables were age and years of education; binary variables were gender, marital status, and employment.

sec.title: General health
sec.p: Self-reported health was assessed by having patients answer the following question: “In general, would you say your health is . . .” and the response scale ranged from 1 to 5 (poor = 1, fair = 2, good = 3, very good = 4, and excellent = 5).

sec.title: Severity of depression
sec.p: The CES-D is a 20-item scale designed to measure symptoms of depression in community populations.48

sec.title: Major depression diagnostic instrument
sec.p: The CIDI (version 2.1)50 is a completely structured psychiatric diagnostic assessment developed for use in cross-national epidemiological studies. Data from the CIDI were used to assess diagnostic criteria for depression from the fourth edition of the American Psychiatric Association’s Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM-IV).51

sec.title: Generic quality of life
sec.p: The WHOQOL-BREF1,2 is a 26-item instrument based on the larger WHOQOL-100, a multilingual assessment for generic quality of life that was developed concurrently across 15 international field centers (see Figure 1).

caption.p: The overall facets of the World Health Organization Quality of Life Instrument–abbreviated version (WHOQOL–BREF) and its 4 domains.

sec.p: The items of the WHOQOL-BREF form 4 domains (physical, psychological, social, and environment) and are answered using individualized 5-point scales. Each subscale is scored positively. This instrument was developed according to the World Health Organization’s definition of QOL as being “an individual’s perception of their position in life in the context of the culture and value systems in which they live and in relation to their goals, expectations, standards and concerns.”52 For example, the item about general QOL and its response scale are as follows: “How would you rate your quality of life?” and the response scale ranges from 1 to 5 (very poor = 1, poor = 2, neither poor nor good = 3, good = 4, and very good = 5).

All measures were obtained concomitantly. Although herein we only describe in detail those instruments whose results were specifically analyzed for the purposes of this article, the LIDO baseline has other instruments53-56 that can be found in detail in Chisholm et al.47

sec.title: Rasch analysis
sec.p: The Rasch analysis was undertaken for each of the 4 domains of the WHOQOL-BREF using the RUMM 2020 package.9 The procedure was similar to that used by Tennant and collaborators.29 In the following explanation of the approach, we have substituted quality of life (QOL) for the term ability (θ), conventionally used in Raschanalysis, and item QOL level for item difficulty (b).

The Rasch model assumes that both the person’s QOL (θ) and the QOL level expressed by an item (b) are measured on the same underlying scale. The probability of a respondent affirming an item (i) is a logistic function of the difference between the person’s QOL (θ) and the QOL level expressed by the item (bi).

where Pni is the probability that person n will endorse item i, θn is the person’s QOL, and bi is the item QOL level. The Rasch model uses the logit (natural log of the odds) as its unit of measurement, an interval scale in which differences between the locations on the person-item map have a consistent value or meaning.57 In the formula above, the term (θn – bi) is on the logit scale.

To extend this model to analyze items with more than 2 categories, a threshold parameter (τ) representing the equal probability point between any 2 adjacent categories within an item is included in the exponent. The logit of endorsing a level of the item is now

in which it is not assumed that the threshold locations are the same for every item, but rather they are allowed to be different for each item.

sec.title: Rasch analysis fit indices
sec.p: To determine model fit, the Rasch analysis considers 3 overall fit statistics. Two are item-person interaction statistics, distributed as Z statistics (the first statistic is the mean and the second is the standard deviation, SD), where having a mean of zero and an SD of 1 will indicate perfect fit to the model.
Thus, for the response of each person to each item, the standardized residuals Zni of the observed score Xni from that predicted by the model, E[Xni], is calculated according to

In the third overall fit statistic, the χ2 item-trait interaction (total items) statistic should be nonsignificant, reflecting the property of invariance across the trait. On the other hand, a significant χ2 indicates that the hierarchical ordering of the items varies across the trait, which fails to confirm the required Rasch property of invariance. In addition, individual item-fit statistics are presented as residuals (the differences between the observed and the expected scores). Model fit for the individual item is acceptable if a) the residual is within the range ±2.5, which is simply the 99% confidence interval, given that the residuals are standardized,18,29 and b) if the item’s residual χ2 statistic is nonsignificant, that is, the null hypothesis is not refuted. High negative residuals are normally interpreted to indicate the redundancy or dependency of an item, and high positive residuals suggest low levels of differentiation and poor fit to the model.12

An estimate of the internal consistency reliability of the scale is also provided, based on the Person Separation Index (PSI), where the estimates on the logit scale for each person were used to calculate reliability.19 A value of 0.7 would indicate the ability to differentiate 2 groups, and 0.8 would allow for 3 groups.58 Traditionally, values above 0.7 would be adequate for group comparison and above 0.85 for individual use.59

sec.title: Steps to Improve Rasch Model Fit
Disordered thresholds
sec.p: Some sources of deviation of model expectations can be identified; thus, the scale can be modified and improved to have better model fit. Given that in this Rasch analysis we are working on polytomous items, the initial step in the analysis is to check whether their response categories are ordered. For instance, on each item, the average of the overall QOL (θn) of the individuals who endorse a higher category should be higher than the average QOL of the individuals who endorse each lower category. If this is not the case, it would mean that the categories are not ordered. The boundaries between categories are called “thresholds.”60 “Disordered thresholds” may indicate that it is necessary to collapse adjacent categories. Usually, collapsing of categories where disordered thresholds occur improves overall fit for the model as it may eliminate the inversion or “disordered” threshold, consequently improving the psychometric properties of the scale.27

sec.title: Differential item functioning
sec.p: Second, we assessed the presence of differential item functioning (DIF) by analyzing each item individually to evaluate whether it displayed DIF for the factor it measured. All persons at a given level of the attribute measured (i.e., at a given scale score, θ) should have an equal probability of endorsing the item regardless of group membership as to sex, age, or other exogenous variables such as, in our case, country of origin. We refer to DIF when this requirement does not hold. The basis for the DIF identification strategy in RUMM 2020 is the item characteristic curve (ICC). The ICC is the expected value curve of the observed response on the item as a function of a latent trait (QOL). There are several statistical procedures for detecting DIF.61,62 The statistical test used in our study for detecting DIF was an analysis of variance (ANOVA)63 using the person-item deviation residuals with person characteristics (e.g., age, gender, country) and class intervals (e.g., group along the trait, person-ability groups) as factors.

Two kinds of DIF can be identified: uniform and nonuniform. In the uniform DIF, there is a constant difference between groups regarding the probability of persons with different levels of QOL affirming a given item. On the other hand, in the nonuniform DIF, that difference varies (i.e., it is not constant) for persons with different levels of QOL. DIF analysis is most commonly used for assessing cross-cultural validity.29 Because there are 6 countries involved in this study, we used the Tukey test as a post hoc test to perform a pairwise comparison of the means to identify where any differences might lie.

Then, after creating a subset of “pure” items (free from DIF) and a subset of “impure” items (that showed DIF),64 we ran a new subtest analysis. A subtest is a “testlet” in classical educational testing, which simply adds together a set of related items (in this case, pure items or impure items) to make a testlet or super item. Its main purpose is to absorb local dependency within sets of items. Our subtest analysis analyzed and compared the two super items created. We then checked DIF again by rerunning the ANOVA to verify whether DIF could be potentially cancelled out and checked whether the data fit the model. If so, we considered all items invariant measures, despite their initial DIF.65 For example, if the people from one country score higher on one item but those from another country score higher on another item within the same latent construct, then overall, the DIF on these 2 items is cancelled out, despite initially seeming to have a DIF.

Only if items displayed DIF for more than one factor (one of them being for country) and had a poor fit to the model were adjustments made to allow these items to vary by group, by using the split procedure29 and deletion of biased items (i.e., those presenting DIF). The split procedure was not adopted for items that only displayed DIF for country, in which case the subtest analysis was used as explained above. Splitting items is a procedure to allow the difficulty of the item to vary by group membership when that item has shown DIF. The approach is repeated until an unbiased set of items is identified. For example, if the “pain” item has DIF for age, it should consequently appear in 2 forms, one for people >40 years (which was the median age of our sample) and another for people <40 years old. These 2 forms of the item are reanalyzed together with unsplit items. Individual item fit and overall measures of fit are again reassessed, and if any split item still displays misfit to the model, then it is removed from the scale and does not contribute to the person estimate.29

sec.title: Local independence
sec.p: Next, looking at the residual correlation matrix, we considered whether any values exceeded 0.3,66,67 which would indicate the presence of local dependence. Local independence requires that the endorsement of an item should not depend on the endorsement of any other item. The endorsement of the work item, for example, should have conditional independence from the endorsement of the activity item for the assessment of people’s work capacity.

sec.title: Unidimensionality
sec.p: Finally, after issues of threshold disordering, DIF, local independence, and fit have been solved, principal components analysis (PCA) of the residuals detects any signs of multidimensionality.68 That is, multidimensionality in the data will be found among items that are loading the most strongly upon the first principal component (i.e., the second dimension). Items may load positively or negatively, yet those that load the strongest in both directions will always be the sets of items that are the most likely to breach the assumption of unidimensionality. Next, the positively and negatively loading items are separated into 2 subsets and are compared using a series of independent t tests to determine whether the person estimates deriving from each subset differ significantly. A t test is performed for each person separately, using the person-specific estimates of ability and person-specific estimates of reliability/variability. For a unidimensional scale, it would be expected that, should the differences in estimates be normally distributed, no more than 5% of such tests would be outside the range ±1.96.69

In the end, when the data fit the model and the requirements of local independence are met, a unidimensional linear scale can be derived from the ordinal raw scores, and the scale is deemed appropriate for valid parametric approaches.26

sec.title: Sample Size Estimation
sec.p: The minimum sample size of 150 individuals is enough to estimate the item difficulty to within ±0.5 logits, with α = 0.01. This sample size is also appropriate for the DIF test, where a difference of 0.5 SD within the residuals for any 2 groups may be detected, with β of 0.20 at an α of 0.01.70

sec.title: Results
sec.p: A total sample of 2359 patients (51% of 4662 eligible cases) participated in the baseline assessment. Compared to those completing the baseline assessment, those declining to participate were slightly younger (mean age 40.5 v. 41.6 years, P = 0.02), were less often female (65% v. 68.6%, P ≤ 0.01), and had lower CES-D scores (24.7 v. 26.4, P < 0.01). Of the 2359 completing the baseline assessment, 1193 (51%) patients with current clinical depression (i.e., meeting DSM-IV criteria for a major depressive episode) were invited to enroll in the longitudinal study. Compared to those not meeting criteria for major depressive episode (n = 1166; 49%), depressed patients had poorer QOL in all WHOQOL-BREF domains as evidenced by mean values of total scores for each domain (physical: 49.9 v. 62.7, P ≤ 0.01; psychological: 45.6 v. 60.7, P ≤ 0.01; environment: 51.1 v. 59.4, P ≤ 0.01; social: 48.5 v. 61.1, P ≤ 0.01). Data presented in Table 1 provide summarized descriptions of the longitudinal sample’s baseline in terms of age, gender, self-reported health and general QOL, severity of depression, and sample sizes. The sample comprised predominantly female, middle-aged patients in good physical health, with moderate levels of depression, and presenting a broad range of self-rated general QOL that varied among countries. The proportion of these depressed patients having poor and very poor QOL varied from 8% in Seattle to 37.7% in St. Petersburg.

sec.title: Preliminary Rasch Analysis of the WHOQOL-BREF Domains
Fit indices
sec.p: Preliminary analysis of each of the 4 WHOQOL-BREF domains showed that they did not meet the expectations of the Rasch model, indicating that they required adjustments. As shown in Table 2, overall measures of model fit for each domain pointed to misfit: Total item χ2 should be low and the P value should be not significant; item fit residual mean should be close to 0 and the SD close to 1. In addition, the physical, psychological, and environment domains had at least 1 item not fitting the model, given that the item residuals should be in the range of ±2.5; the χ2 should be low and the P value should be not significant. The property of unidimensionality was violated in the physical (8% of t tests outside the range ±1.96) and environment domains (6% of t tests outside the range ±1.96) because no more than 5% of the t tests should have exceeded the range. Internal consistency reliability estimates varied among domains: physical (PSI = 0.78), psychological (PSI = 0.74), environment (PSI = 0.73), and social (PSI = 0.58). Given that values above 0.7 are indicative of the ability of the scale to differentiate 2 groups, all except the social domain showed adequacy for group comparison. The majority of WHOQOL-BREF items were found to have an additive structure and an interval-level scale. Only 2 items had to be rescored—sleep and home—because of disordered thresholds of category responses (Figure 2).

sec.title: Differential item functioning
sec.p: We assessed the presence of DIF to ensure the invariance of WHOQOL-BREF domains as individuals with the same score on the test are expected to have the same probability of response to an item, irrespective of any group membership. All items were checked for DIF for age, gender, and country, as shown in Table 3. Some items showed DIF for 2 person factors: medication (age, country), positive feelings (age, country), thinking (age, country), body (gender, country), and activity (age, country). Items displayed DIF for country (5 of 26 items), age (4 of 26 items), and gender (1 of 26 items). No item showed DIF for more than 2 factors.

sec.p: Because no domain met all model requirements, data presented below correspond to Rasch adjustments using each stage of the analysis protocol described in the Methods section. To illustrate the analysis process, only the analysis of the physical domain items will be presented in detail. The psychological, environment, and social domain items were analyzed using the same rationale and process; however, except for the final solution, which can be seen in Table 4, the results will not be presented in detail herein.

sec.title: Physical Domain Items
sec.p: Deleting the sleep and activity items for people <40 years old resulted in the best overall measures of fit for the physical domain, where the item fit residual mean (SD) changed from 0.49 (2.59) to 0.58 (1.05); person fit residual mean (SD) changed from −0.37 (1.23) to −0.35 (1.14); total χ2 changed from 161.5 to 62.5; and P value changed from <0.001 to 0.19. The sleep item was rescored, collapsing category responses by suppressing the middle category (Figure 2). This item was then removed because, after rescoring, it persisted in showing misfit (residual = 3.56; χ2 = 21.8; P = 0.01). No item from the physical domain had correlations >0.3 in the person item residual correlation matrix, indicating local independence of responses. Because the activity item displayed DIF for age, it was split, and Activity for people <40 years old was removed (residual = −3.59; χ2 = 35.8; P < 0.001). The medication item was also split by age group (overall χ2 = 104.9; P < 0.001), yet removing this item for people <40 years (residual = 0.21; χ2 = 25.9; P = 0.002) did not improve overall measures of fit (total item χ2 = 71.5; P = 0.06; item fit residual mean [SD] = 0.72 [1.18]; person fit residual mean [SD] = −0.39 [1.18]), as compared to the best solution, which was to maintain the medication item. For the best Rasch adjustment for the physical domain, the percentage of individuals with extreme t tests decreased from 8% to 5%. The purification procedure resulted in removing the DIF for age. The internal consistency reliability estimate (PSI) changed from 0.78 to 0.75.

sec.title: Rasch and Raw Score Correlations
sec.p: Raw score data are often analyzed as if they were composed of interval scores. One of the key features of the Rasch analysis is precisely to provide a score that actually is on an interval scale. In our study, we adjusted WHOQOL-BREF domain scores using the Rasch analysis, and then we correlated raw and Rasch scores (interval scores). The correlations between raw and Rasch scores were very high (physical domain = 0.96, psychological domain = 0.94, environment domain = 0.97, social domain = 0.99; P < 0.001). This demonstrates that the raw scores are strongly linearly related to the interval-scaled Rasch scores.

sec.title: Targeting of Each of the 4 Domains of the WHOQOL-BREF
sec.p: Figure 3 shows the targeting of each of the 4 domains of the WHOQOL-BREF. In each figure (a, b, c, and d), the distribution of persons is shown in the top half and the items’ thresholds in the bottom half. The overall mean person locations for physical (Figure 3a), psychological (Figure 3b), environment (Figure 3c), and social (Figure 3d) domains are 0.085, −0.478, −0.076, and −0.112, respectively. All these means demonstrate that the items of the 4 domains are well targeted for this population, as the values are close to zero, which is the center of the scale.

sec.title: Cross-Cultural Invariance of the WHOQOL-BREF Items—Results from DIF Analysis
Results from each country
sec.p: The WHOQOL-BREF domains showed a good fit to the Rasch model when each country sample was analyzed separately. The most significant adjustment made was that of rescoring, which had to be done for each sample, although for different items. The sleep item had to be removed from all samples, except for those of the United States and Israel. Local dependency of responses was identified between the activity and work items for the Brazilian23 and Spanish samples. The same was true for the pain and medication items for the Russian data. Local dependence means that the endorsement of one item depends on the endorsement of another item—for example, the endorsement of the pain item depends on that of the medication item, even after controlling for the latent Rasch factor.

sec.title: Results of pooling data from all countries
sec.p: Using only ANOVA, we found that 15 items showed DIF among different countries (Table 5). If we look at the post hoc analysis, we can observe that most items have DIF only between 1 and 2 countries v. the remainder. Only 1 item displayed DIF for more than 2 countries. Five items were free from any country-related DIF. The Tukey test was not carried out for split or deleted items because the RUMM 2020 does not provide the required estimates for this calculation.

sec.p: After a purification procedure using a subtest analysis comparing “pure” and “impure” items, all DIF for country was shown to have been removed for all domains, as shown by the ANOVA for physical (pure: F = 1.03, P = 0.41; impure: F = 1.08, P = 0.97), psychological (pure: F = 1.38, P = 0.23; impure: F = 0.72, P = 0.61), environment (pure: F = 0.43, P = 0.82; impure: F = 1.10, P = 0.35), and social (pure: F = 0.77, P = 0.84; impure: F = 1.72, P = 0.13) domains. Also, overall measures of model fit for each domain were as follows: physical (total item χ2 = 17.2; P = 0.51; item fit residual mean [SD] = 0.26 [3.46]; person fit residual mean [SD] = −0.64 [0.67]), psychological (total item χ2 = 14.4; P = 0.64; item fit residual mean [SD] = −0.45 [3.47]; person fit residual mean [SD] = −0.60 [0.62]), environment (total item χ2 = 5.8; P = 0.99; item fit residual mean [SD] = −3.54 [14.78]; person fit residual mean [SD] = −0.55 [0.97]), and social (total item χ2 = 29.9; P = 0.02; item fit residual mean [SD] = −0.001 [6.52]; person fit residual mean [SD] = −0.59 [1.12]).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Our findings describe the measurement properties of the WHOQOL-BREF domains as measures of generic QOL, as well as the cross-cultural invariance of items, by using a Rasch analysis in the context of depressed primary care patients in 6 countries worldwide. This is the first study to assess these issues in a population with such characteristics. Other studies that had a similar purpose used CTT, smaller sample sizes, or patients from a clinical setting from a single culture,36,37,71,72 thereby limiting the generalization of their results.

Overall, the cross-cultural Rasch analysis of the WHOQOL-BREF items demonstrated that a) 5 items were free from DIF and b) 14 items displayed DIF for only 1 or 2 countries. Of the remaining 7 items, 3 were excluded and 3 had to be modified to satisfy the Rasch model. Only 1 item, that of social relationships, showed DIF for more than 2 countries. Despite these several items displaying DIF, we still consider the WHOQOL-BREF a good cross-cultural measure of QOL in depressed patients. The argument that supports this assertion is that although the DIF methodology used in our study tends to show a certain degree of significant DIF, statistically such results would not have practical/clinical significance because our sample was especially large (n = 1193).

To our knowledge, there is no study comparing the WHOQOL-BREF domains cross-culturally among non-European countries using the Rasch analysis. The study by Leplege and others73 is the most similar to ours as it also studies a WHOQOL measure in non-European countries. Using the WHOQOL-100 (not the BREF), they found that only 1 item had cross-cultural equivalence among the 4 cultures studied (France, Hong Kong, Argentina, and the United Kingdom). In this setting, there were more marked divergences between Argentina and the United Kingdom than between the United Kingdom and Hong Kong. Excluding Argentina from the analysis, they found 12 DIF-free items (general health, finances, environment, thinking, meaning in life, opportunities of acquiring new skills, information, 2 items regarding transport, pain, personal relationships, and negative feelings). The difference between their findings and ours may be explained by the fact that they used a different approach, by analyzing all items together in a single analysis, disregarding the domains. In our study, we analyzed the items within the 4 domains, which may have increased our likelihood of finding DIF given that our study involved at least one analysis for each domain. Also, their study excluded participants who did not fit the model, which compromises the generalization of the WHOQOL-BREF for those excluded (i.e., people who had extremescores on health-related questions). Furthermore, the study by Leplege and others73 used a range between −3.5 and 3.5 of residual values to exclude persons and items, whereas our range was narrower and therefore stricter (between −2.5 and 2.5), which also might have influenced our findings.

The finding that age is an important factor in item functioning is in agreement with some current research.46,74 Therefore, any QOL measure should take into account the need for specific measures for different age populations. This has been a concern of some authors who have been working on the design of specific instruments for older people46 and for children.74

When using the Rasch analysis and deciding whether to remove an item, we should consider the item’s performance in all steps of the analysis. The analysis of the items at the country level is an important step, and a suitable performance at the country level is a basic feature that the item must have before the subsequent steps may be taken. The body image item was excluded even though it fit the Rasch model when the WHOQOL-BREF was analyzed using individual country samples. A possible explanation is that the concept of body image cannot be compared between cultures and genders for depressed primary care patients. The exclusion of the sleep item because of its poor fit is not related to cross-cultural issues because it functioned poorly both at the country level and when the entire sample was analyzed. The exclusion of the transport item might be a result that cannot be generalized to all samples studied because this item had a good fit at the country level, and its exclusion did not much improve overall measures of model fit.

However, modifying the WHOQOL-BREF by deleting items to improve its performance as a Rasch measure can reduce its comparability with previous WHOQOL studies. Therefore, our challenge as researchers was to maintain the structure of the WHOQOL-BREF as close as possible to the original one even after the Rasch analysis. Other studies have found issues related to mental health and social adjustment that could be considered in QOL measures for depression, such as stigma, barriers to treatment,75 existential well-being (autonomy, freedom), and religiosity, which are not part of the short form of the WHOQOL. The inclusion of these aspects could improve reliability and validity76 of the construct that is being measured, mainly by improving the social domain’s inadequate psychometric performance.

The present study did not reexamine the basis for the original 4-domain structure of the WHOQOL-BREF, which may be a limitation, regardless of the fact that there is no consensus on the most suitable method to evaluate instrument dimensionality.77 As a consequence, we decided to maintain the 4-domain structure because besides being the most conventional structure, it is also the most studied one.78 Analyzing all WHOQOL-BREF items together to see whether they form a unidimensional and meaningful measure would not be a reasonable strategy. Future investigations may be necessary to test the multidimensional structure of WHOQOL-BREF under a multidimensional Rasch model.

A valid measure of QOL in depressed patients has important clinical implications. It allows for the evaluation of relevant facets that are not part of the patient’s routine assessment, by providing additional information that could contribute to a better understanding of the repercussions of the severity of a major depression diagnosis in a patient’s life.79 In our opinion, clinical improvement depends on other factors that are not addressed by the most commonly used therapeutic approaches, nor are they measured by exclusively symptomatic assessments that do not reflect a reliable and valid evaluation of patients’ improvement or impairment during their treatment.

Finally, with some adjustments, the WHOQOL-BREF domains are suitable cross-cultural measures of generic QOL for depressed primary care patients. Our study mostly confirms the product of the construction of the WHOQOL-BREF as guided by CTT, given that only 6 items required adjustments.
